sections.title: Negation in Classical Tibetan
sections.content: Negation is one of the most important grammatical structures in classical Tibetan, especially in Buddhist philosophical texts. The Prajnaparamita literature — particularly the Heart Sutra — is built almost entirely on negation: 'no form, no feeling, no perception... no eyes, no ears...' Classical Tibetan uses different negation particles depending on the tense and type of statement: མི (mi) negates present and future verbs, མ (ma) negates past verbs and forms prohibitions, མིན (min) negates equations ('is not'), and མེད (med) negates existence ('does not exist'). Buddhist logic also employs double negation to express the Middle Way — neither affirming nor denying existence. In this lesson, we study these negation patterns with examples drawn from the Heart Sutra, the 37 Practices of Bodhisattvas, and Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer.

example.note: From the Heart Sutra. མི placed before the verb negates present/future actions.
མ before a past-tense verb negates a completed action.
མིན is the negative of ཡིན (to be). It negates identity or classification.

words.english: does not exist, there is no (negates ཡོད)

example.transliteration: mig med rna ba med sna med
example.english: There are no eyes, no ears, no nose.
example.literalTranslation: Eyes not-exist. Ears not-exist. Nose not-exist.
example.note: From the Heart Sutra. མེད negates the existence of the sense organs in emptiness.

example.transliteration: stong pa nyid gzugs las gzhan ma yin
example.english: Emptiness is not other than form.
example.note: From the Heart Sutra. མ་ཡིན is the full form of མིན, used in formal philosophical statements.

example.transliteration: bdag med pa ni chos kyi gnas lugs yin
example.english: Selflessness is the nature of phenomena.
example.note: མེད་པ is the nominalized form — 'the state of not existing' — used as a noun.

words.english: form, matter (first of the five aggregates)

example.transliteration: gzugs stong pa'o stong pa nyid gzugs so
example.english: Form is emptiness. Emptiness is form.
example.note: The most famous lines of the Heart Sutra. The negation of form's inherent existence.

example.transliteration: shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa
example.note: The title of the Prajnaparamita sutras. ཤེས་རབ is the wisdom that sees emptiness through negation.

example.transliteration: sgrib pa med pas 'jigs pa med
example.english: Because there is no obscuration, there is no fear.
example.note: From the Heart Sutra. Double use of མེད — the absence of obscuration leads to the absence of fear.
From the Heart Sutra. The famous negation of arising and ceasing — the nature of emptiness.

sections.title: མི — Present and Future Negation
sections.rule: Negating present and future actions with མི
sections.explanation: The particle མི (mi) is placed directly before the verb to negate present and future tense actions. It expresses that something does not happen, is not happening, or will not happen. In the Heart Sutra, མི is used extensively to negate the characteristics of phenomena in emptiness: མི་སྐྱེ (does not arise), མི་འགག (does not cease), མི་དྲི་མ (not defiled), མི་གཙང (not pure), མི་བྲི (does not diminish), མི་འཕེལ (does not increase). This pattern of negation reveals the ultimate nature of reality as taught in the Prajnaparamita.

examples.transliteration: chos thams cad stong pa nyid de, mi skye mi 'gag, mi dri ma med mi gtsang ba med
examples.english: All phenomena are emptiness — not arising, not ceasing, not defiled, not pure.
examples.note: From the Heart Sutra. The series of མི negations describes the eight qualities of emptiness (neither arising nor ceasing, neither defiled nor pure, neither increasing nor decreasing).

examples.transliteration: rgyal sras bdag nyid kyi bde ba mi 'tshol
examples.english: The bodhisattva does not seek happiness for himself.
examples.note: In the spirit of the 37 Practices. མི before འཚོལ (to seek) negates the present action.

examples.transliteration: stong pa'i ngang la chos mi dmigs
examples.english: In the state of emptiness, phenomena are not apprehended.
examples.note: A key Prajnaparamita teaching. མི་དམིགས means 'not apprehended' — nothing can be grasped in the state of emptiness.

sections.title: མ — Past and Imperative Negation
sections.rule: Negating past actions and forming prohibitions with མ
sections.explanation: The particle མ (ma) negates past tense verbs and forms prohibitions (negative imperatives, i.e. 'do not!'). For past negation, མ is placed before the past stem: མ་བྱས (did not do), མ་སོང (did not go), མ་བསྒོམས (did not meditate). For prohibitions, མ is placed before the imperative or present stem: མ་བྱེད (don't do!), མ་སོང (don't go!), མ་སྤོང (don't abandon!). Context distinguishes past negation from prohibition — past negation describes what didn't happen, while prohibitions are commands directed at the listener.

examples.transliteration: rgyal sras kyis nyon mongs la dbang ma byin
examples.english: The bodhisattva did not give power to the afflictions.
examples.note: In the spirit of the 37 Practices. མ before the past stem བྱིན negates the completed action.

examples.transliteration: nyon mongs kyi dbang du ma song
examples.english: Do not fall under the power of the afflictions!
examples.note: From the spirit of the 37 Practices. མ་སོང is a prohibition: 'don't go!' The imperative of འགྲོ is སོང.

examples.transliteration: kun tu bzang pos smon lam ma btab na byang chub mi thob
examples.english: If Samantabhadra had not made aspiration prayers, enlightenment would not be attained.
examples.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. Shows both མ (past negation) and མི (present/future negation) in the same sentence.

sections.title: མིན/མེད — Existential Negation and Double Negation
sections.rule: Negating existence and identity; double negation in Buddhist logic
sections.explanation: མིན (min) is the negative of ཡིན (to be) and negates identity: 'X is not Y'. མེད (med) is the negative of ཡོད (to exist) and negates existence: 'X does not exist'. The formal variant མ་ཡིན is used in philosophical texts. These two negations are central to Buddhist philosophy — the Heart Sutra uses མེད extensively to negate the existence of phenomena in emptiness. Buddhist logic also uses double negation: མེད་པ་མ་ཡིན (not non-existent) does not simply mean 'existent' but points to a reality beyond both existence and non-existence — the Middle Way (དབུ་མ). This is how the Prajnaparamita literature avoids both eternalism and nihilism.

examples.transliteration: stong pa nyid la gzugs med tshor ba med 'du shes med 'du byed med rnam shes med
examples.english: In emptiness there is no form, no feeling, no perception, no formation, no consciousness.
examples.note: From the Heart Sutra. The five aggregates (ཕུང་པོ་ལྔ) are each negated with མེད — they do not exist as inherently real in emptiness.

examples.transliteration: chos rnams bden pa min rdzun pa yang min
examples.english: Phenomena are not true. Nor are they false.
examples.note: A Middle Way (Madhyamaka) statement. Neither affirming nor denying — this is how Buddhist logic uses double negation to point beyond conceptual extremes.

examples.transliteration: sgrib pa med pas 'jigs pa med de phyin ci log las shin tu 'das nas mya ngan las 'das par phyin to
examples.english: Because there is no obscuration, there is no fear; having completely passed beyond error, one reaches nirvana.
examples.note: From the Heart Sutra. A chain of negations: no obscuration → no fear → beyond error → nirvana. This shows how negation leads to liberation in Prajnaparamita.

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.description: Practice identifying and using negation particles in classical Buddhist texts

keyPoints.text: མི (mi) negates present and future tense verbs: མི་སྐྱེ (does not arise), མི་འགག (does not cease)
མི is placed directly before the verb it negates
The Heart Sutra uses མི extensively to describe the eight qualities of emptiness
མ (ma) negates past tense verbs: མ་བྱས (did not do), མ་སོང (did not go)
མ also forms prohibitions (negative imperatives): མ་བྱེད (don't do!), མ་སོང (don't go!)
མིན negates ཡིན (is not) for identity; མེད negates ཡོད (does not exist) for existence
མ་ཡིན is the formal variant of མིན, used in philosophical texts
Double negation (མེད་པ་མ་ཡིན 'not non-existent') points to the Middle Way beyond existence and non-existence
